content:
Not really difficult, especially when you can cheat as i did (not really cheating but in php i have tricks)

I modified the goal that did not mention the case "No solution!"

Oh, thanks for modifying that!
And wich kind of tricks are you talking about?

Completely rewritten/rearranged the text.

1. Spent some time trying to implement a tree / graph... and eventually discarding all different ideas and use mainly loops and string operations in solving the puzzle. I'd like to know if there are any cases where a graph must be used to solve.

2. Removed "You can assume 1 ≤ N ≤ 10." from input section. The same has been mentioned in constraints section.

3. Changed in the constraints section: lower limit of M is 0 instead of 1.

4. The author please refer to the guidelines on how inputs and outputs should be written. (In case you don't know, the guidelines can be found by clicking the question marks next to the section headings.)

Your original version copied here for your reference:
An integer [[N]], followed by [[N]] variables in lexicographical order, followed by the number of equations [[M]], followed by [[M]] equations.
Print in lexicographical order of the variables the general solution of the system.

5. The author please always give meaningful names to test cases and validators. I've renamed them all, though I'm not satisfied with the last two pairs.

6. Revised some test cases/validators for a bit more variety/complexity.

(a) Example validator
Original version:
c = f ( a b )
b = h ( a )

(b) Self-reference test case
Original version:
x = f ( x )

(c) Self-reference validator
Original version:
x = f ( x )
y = f ( z )

7. Revised certain functions' names because they violate the constraint that each function contains the same number of arguments. Also revised a 3-letter variable name to 2-letter.

8. If a variable never appears in the left side of the equations, "variable -> variable" should be output.

But for No equations test case/validator, the logic is weird. If there are 0 equations as input, there should be 0 solution?

Will still approve despite point 8, but I hope there's some way to resolve the issue or provide a satisfactory explanation.

Well, i have to learn to write statements.
Thanks for all.

About graphs, my solution only uses graphs and a simple string concatenation function. This problem can be solved as a well-known graph problem (Topological sorting) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_sorting
And this method it's really efficient compared to repeated string substitution.
Thanks for the information! Maybe a version with many more variables/equations would need graph implementation to avoid timeout?

Yes, i was limited by input size, but this problem is inspirated from a contest problem, and the input was big (up to 10^4 lines). In that case, you need an algorithm that takes O(n log n) or better time. With topological sort, time is linear O(n).

OK, understood now.

Also I'd really like to know your view on point 8.

About point 8, yes, all declared variables should be printed in the solved form, so, a variable without a function declaration gets self function as value.
It can be viewed as all funcions are initially declared like f -> f and then they can be overwriten by a new declaration.
Or a non-declared function it's just self
Thanks for your explanation. I'll add that to the statement to clarify.
